Document Text: A joint resolution to authorize the use of United States Armed Forces against Iraq.
Result: Cloture Motion Agreed to (95-1, 3/5 majority required)

Vote Title: Motion to Table Graham Amdt. No. 4857
Document Text: To provide substitute language that includes an authorization for the use of the United States Armed Forces to defend the national security of the United States against the threat posed by certain foreign terrorist organizations.

Question: On the Amendment S.Amdt. 4869 to S.J.Res. 45 (Further Resolution on Iraq)
Vote Title: Byrd Amdt. No. 4869, As Amended
Document Text: To provide a termination date for the authorization of the use of the Armed Forces of the United States, together with procedures for the extension of such date unless Congress disapproves the extension.

Vote Title: Motion to Invoke Cloture on the Lieberman Amdt. No. 4856
Document Text: In the nature of a substitute.
Result: Cloture Motion Agreed to (75-25, 3/5 majority required)

Question: On the Amendment S.Amdt. 4868 to S.Amdt. 4856 to S.J.Res. 45 (Further Resolution on Iraq)
Vote Title: Byrd Amdt. No. 4868
Document Text: To provide statutory construction that constitutional authorities remain unaffected and that no additional grant of authority is made to the President not directly related to the existing threat posed by Iraq.

Question: On the Amendment S.Amdt. 4862 to S.Amdt. 4856 to S.J.Res. 45 (Further Resolution on Iraq)
Vote Title: Levin Amdt. No. 4862
Document Text: To authorize the use of the United States Armed Forces, pursuant to a new resolution of the United Nations Security Council, to destroy, remove, or render harmless Iraq's weapons of mass destruction, nuclear weapons-usable material, long-range ballistic missiles, and related facilities, and for other purposes.

Question: On the Amendment S.Amdt. 4865 to S.Amdt. 4856 to S.J.Res. 45 (Further Resolution on Iraq)
Vote Title: Durbin Amdt. No. 4865
Document Text: To amend the authorization for the use of the Armed Forces to cover an imminent threat posed by Iraq's weapons of mass destruction rather than the continuing threat posed by Iraq.
